results.justification: The document explicitly states the research methodology, focusing on causal modeling to understand the relationship between GAI-assisted writing behaviors and essay quality. (e.g., 'we used causal modeling...to identify causal relationships')

Sections 3.1, 3.2, 3.3, and 3.4 provide a detailed, step-by-step description of the study design, including dataset selection, conceptual model creation, causal effect identification and estimation, and evaluation methods.

The document explicitly mentions the dataset used: 'We chose a publicly available dataset, CoAuthor [44], containing 1,445 GAI-assisted writing sessions...' and provides a link: 'https://coauthor.stanford.edu/'
Data is publicly available, so justification for non-sharing is not applicable.
The document references a detailed description of the dataset in [44] and provides information about the variables used (Section 3.2, Table 1).
The data collection methods are described in Section 3.1, detailing the recruitment of writers from a crowd-sourcing platform and the writing tasks they participated in.
The document provides a link to a GitHub repository containing the analysis code: 'https://github.com/CarsonYang518/LAK25-GAI-Writing-Causal'
Code is publicly available, so justification for non-sharing is not applicable.
The document states that the code is available in the linked GitHub repository, implying that data preparation code is also included.
Statistical tests (X-learner algorithms), models (Directed Acyclic Graph), and assumptions (back-door criterion) are clearly described in Section 3.3.
Effect sizes (ATE), and p-values are reported in Table 2 and discussed in Section 4.1.
The study is primarily quantitative; subjective context and interpretation are limited.
The study is primarily quantitative; data coding and analysis are not described in a qualitative manner.
Results are clearly presented in Table 2 and discussed in Section 4.1, with specific findings highlighted.
Limitations are discussed in Section 4.3, including the dataset's generalizability, limited writer information, and data imbalance.
The document does not contain a link to a preregistration on platforms like the Open Science Foundation.
